title: I didn't love it as much as I wanted to
text:
I am a compulsive baker with an embarrassingly large collection of dessert/baking cookbooks. For another book to make it onto the crowded shelves it has to stand out with unique recipes and techniques. While there are many excellent recipes in this collection that I am thrilled to have is there anyone out there who is thinking; if only I had another recipe for Mexican Wedding Cookies?

They are stingy with the photographs and it is very disappointing that of the pictures included none are of some of the more elaborate desserts where you would like to see what the final product looks like. Instead there are pictures of chocolate chip cookies, pots de creme, gingersnaps, flan, bread pudding, sorbet and frozen yogurt. That is just plain annoying. I would gladly pay more for a book that is well photographed.

I have a great deal of respect for David Lebovitz and was excited to be one of the first to get a look at his new title. There are some books I can say unequivocally, buy it you will love it. This one I would recommend looking through it first to see if it is something you would enjoy.

*Update: Obviously my comments on the book struck a chord among the obsessive bakers/ cookbook collectors out there. It has been bothering me though that other than my comment on the amount of recipes included that I dismissed as too common most were really complaints the publisher was responsible for. I want to update this review with a response to a question on the quality of the recipes in the discussion section for those who don't usually check in on those...

All recipes I have tried from this book do work, and they are clearly written. Many of the recipes are adaptations of classics with David's spin. I probably did a disservice to David by focusing on the book from my point of view as an accomplished baker comfortable adapting and tweaking recipes to suit my own taste. I think the real strength and value in this book is the amount of tips and advice David provides. It would be great for anyone who would like a book to teach them about baking and dessert making instead of just providing recipes. David's humorous conversational writing style is a big plus too.

title: DISAPOINTMENT
text:
I read the first two books of the Tawny Man and was thrilled, but then I read the third.

It seemed to me that Hobb was leading us down a certain path with these books, but then at the end of Fool's Fate swurved and tumbled of a cliff.

The story is not in keeping with the previous books rhythm! We learn that the majority of his emotions thus far are because he "dulled" the edges of his world and he miraculously get them back and the world is once again crystal clear as is his love for Molly, whom was already described as just a youthful love. No, now it is true love and oh! since she's available now (strange coincidence)he can go get her back!

Angered? Yes I was, but I could have been fine with this upset that is until she dismissed the Fool. All that happens, all that they were put through and the sacrifices that they made for one another and yet in the end he is completely dismissed form Fitz's life as just another sad memory, another regret? No, that I couldn't stand. The Fool loved him, that was made clear long ago and yet now that they are closer than they have ever been he can simply leave? I understand that he was put under a trumendous ordeal, but even that pales to the sudden attitude the Fool has at the end and really the only word I can think of to describe it is exactly that "a dismissal".

Starting at the scene before Girl-on-a-Dragon and leading up to the cabin and Fitz's diparture the book begins to fall apart. It feels as if we are being led in a direction and then swiflty turned about the other rode forgotten as well as all the possiblities it held.

I dearly loved the Farseer Trilogy, in fact I still do, but this new trilogy has now spoiled it for me. I caution anyone who loved that trilogy as much as me and who loved the Fool, don't read these books. Simply stop at the last trilogy because you'll be dissapointed.

Angela.

title: A little disappointing but still great fun
text:
This is one of John Mortimer's last contributions to the Rumpole canon, published just two years before his death, and it is not one of his best.

Although the story is amusing overall and has a much sharper socio-political edge to it, the storytelling and writing style lack a lot of the spark of Mortimer's earlier work. Some the characters, like Liz Probert and Sam Ballard, have evolved in ways that might seem inconsistent with their earlier personalities, which Mortimer had brought to life so convincingly.

John Mortimer experimented further with telling some of the story from Hilda's point of view, which he introduced in earlier works. This technique works particularly well with respect to one of the subplots in this book.

title: good story line but hard to read writing style
text:
I liked the story line but didn't enjoy William Gibson's writing style. His sentences often didn't seem complete (missing/implied pronouns) and there were many others from which I could drive no meaning even after repeated readings.

The first one hundred or so pages I felt lost with no key to unlocking the secret code. A glossary of the authors invented terms/processes/items would have helped immensely. I would have given up early on if I hadn't been reading this for my local book club meeting. I gave up on trying to understand much of what Mr. Gibson was writing, and settle for following the basics of the plot line, which I did enjoy.

The story starts in some point after 2023 in the United States. Flynne Fisher is an ex-gamer, but just this once she agrees to sub for her brother and work his shift beta testing a game. Well, she does it again the next night and this time all doesn't go so well. Some one in the game is killed in a gruesome manner and she begins to question whether it really is a game.

The story skips back and forth between Flynne's time and a future time, about seventy years from them. In the future, Wilf Netherton has some involvement with the death that occurred and it's important to him to protect Flynne from any backlash from that event.

The character of Flynne is well developed and I found her down to earth and likable. She is very family oriented and ethical. She sticks to her morals even when large amounts of money are waved in front of her face. My other favourite character is Conner, a long time friend who is ex-military with multiple crippling war injuries. He's in your face, does what he needs to with no apologies.

This story made me ponder the role of technology in society. Change used to be a long time coming, but now, technology seems to change almost over night. Download a file, a bam, with a 3D printer you can have a new product in hours. Who's to decide/determine whether this is good or bad.

All things considered, I enjoyed the story line and had no trouble believing the bridging of the time differences, I only wish that it had been easier to read and understand the actual wording.

text:
Two newly married snobs enjoy the high life while investigating a murder. The chef/owner of a popular eatery angers his wealthy neighbors with his plans to expand into a courtyard that houses a historically significant fountain. When a skeleton is discovered, it triggers fears of an ancient curse. But the body is of more recent vintage and triggers an investigation into royalists that will take magistrate Verlique and his bride, professor Bonnet, down a twisted trail of criminal enterprise including human trafficking and drugs.

title: Decent summary of Padres' history
text:
Padres Essential: Everything You Need To Know To Be A Real Fan is a short history of the San Diego Padres written by the Padres beat reporter for the San Diego Union-Tribune, Bill Center. This is a concise, entertaining look at the 40-year history of the franchise that you'll read in a couple of sittings. The book was published in 2007 so lame duck team owner, John Moores, who drove the franchise into the ground the last five years is referred to quite positively. Even so, Padres Essential is a valuable read.

Padres Essential was published the same year as Bob Chandler's Tales From The San Diego Padres Dugout but it's far and away the superior publication. "Tales" was written at an eighth grade level while Padres Essential was written for adults and has more material. My biggest gripe about "Tales" was it never even mentioned the greatest Padres tale; Goose Gossage lambasting team owner Joan Kroc in 1986 for removing beer from the clubhouse. Center at least mentions the incident although not in any detail.

Most seasons we Padres fans are only hoping for a .500 season so we've learned not to aim too high. There are no great Padres books out there but Padres Essential is better than nothing (and better than Bob Chandler's Tales From The San Diego Padres Dugout).

title: Not what I expected.....
text:
I don’t know, but I just didn’t get this book. It certainly was not what I expected.

There was a lot of scene switching, going from present to past, and sometimes to symbolical or allegorical scenes.

Aside from the fascinating views of pre-world war Jewish daily life and the concentration camp scenes, I found the sex scenes and child molestation episodes a bit graphic and mostly unnecessary to the telling of the story.

The book was interesting, but not something I would usually read.

I received an advance review copy for free, and I am leaving this review voluntarily.

title: A blood- soaked trail from Mexico to Texas
text:
" The House of the Rising Sun" by James Lee Burke is a story set in Texas and takes place in the years just after the turn of the 20th. century. It's hero is Hackberry Holland, former Texas Ranger and town Marshall, though hero may be the wrong word to describe him.
In most western stories, the hero is a man who can be described as a good man to have as a friend and a bad one to have as an enemy. Think of Shane of the classic movie western. Hack Holland, however, is a bad man to have as a friend and worse to have as an enemy.
He is a sociopath, possibly a psychopath, an alcoholic with muderous rages in which he is quite likely to beat a man to the ground and keep pounding on him until the red mists before his eyes fades away. Not a man to mess with-- or love. That is the main character of this book.
Moreover, there is not one of the important characters in the book who is much better. Lust , greed, revenge, willful pride are the motivating factors of the story, which is saying something, considering it is about a search for the Holy Grail. Yes that Holy Grail. Hack finds it, and the one who had it wants it back and wants it badly enough to kill and torture his way through Mexico and Texas to get it.
That being said, "The House of the Rising Sun" is one heck of a novel.
Mr. Burke writes beautifully, compelling the reader to pay attention. He paints colorful landscapes for his novel, with the hill country of Texas and the sere Mexican desert hardly big enough to contain the action. His characters,even the supporting players, to use a movie term, live on the pages, at least until someone kills them.Burke somehow, but with great skill, even makes Hack Holland a sympathetic character, as he combats his homicidal urges, wallows in his remorse for his treatment of his family and contemplates a life without one friend to his name.
Burke gets a bit of philosophical musing in, writing, ".Was not all mankind adrift on a dark sea, without hope, at the mercy of undercurrents, waves big as mountains...." At one time, when Hack's woman, the mother of his son finds him in a cage, drunk, beaten and filthy, his recent war wounds barely healed over, she " ...takes his weight across her thighs, his arms hanging loose...the bones of his chest prominent...." A Pieta - like scene. Burke does like to use purple prose to paint a powerful picture.

I had not read too much of Burke's work before this book, maybe one or two of the Robicheaux thrillers. This one was certainly different and I will look into more of the Hack Holland books just to see how he became the man he was.

Recommended , with the warning there violent and sometimes disturbing scenes. Also sexual references, though no graphic sex. Also some late night, last drink before closing the bar down,philosophical musing going on to try to raise the level from a hell-bent western.

title: Garbage, straight up
text:
So let's see. A book claiming to be new, uses old and well established and well known information. Still fails to help explain the important part that is near impossible for people to quantify: how to identify the trigger for an action.

Maybe if this book actually helped with that part a whole lot more than they do, it would have been worth the money. As is, I'm disappointed. 90% of the book is just story after story as examples, but they don't add substance to the point of the book at all. The total substance of important things in the book is like the last 10-20 pages. The rest could (and should) be skipped, entirely.

In contrast the book "how we decide" has much more pertinent information.

title: Mostly Tedious With Occasional Flashes of Brillance
text: 1970. A castle in Italy, Three twenty -something Brits are vacationing, Keith who spends his time reading classic British novels of the 18th and 19th centuries, Lily, his girlfriend who frets about not being beautiful enough and Schehrazade, Lily's friend who is tall, exquisitely beautiful and vacuous. A subsidiary cast is also present, Whittaker, a gay man and his Middle Eastern lover Amen, Adriano, a rich midget count who has his eyes on Schehrazade, Gloria who has a superb 'arse' and various others. All of them spend almost 400 boring pages obsessing over Schehrazade's gorgeous breasts. Will Keith get to have sex with her? Will there be consequences? The guys seem perplexed finding themselves in the midst of the sexual revoluation where girls want and have sex as much as they do. As a Baby Boomer who was the same age as these young folk back in 1970 I found this all tedious in the extreme. True every once in awhile there is a flash of brilliant observation by Amis put into the mouth of a now aging Keith giving us a peek into the future. Literary references abound. Yes, I get it Amis is writing a 1970's comedy of manners like the novels read by Keith. Still the slog through this dull book just isn't worth the effort, and Amis makes the Italian castle setting about as interesting as a stay on an iceberg in Antarctica.

title: Well...
text: It started out a little slow but I was very interested in the main character Diana, so I kept plugging along.  I almost put it down when the I OWN YOU & YOU DO WHAT I SAY crap started.  Matthew is your typical 1500 year old vampire in a romance.  He hasn't learned over the years that women don't want to be told what to do anymore.  Apparently the author hasn't figured that out either.  I stopped reading when Diana and Matthew got to Diana's family home and her aunts started in as well, that was enough for me.  If you want that kind of crap in your romance pick up the usual paperback romance novels. Don't waste your time on this one, it's too long for that.

title: good story but, not a fan or the writing style
text:
I started and stopped this book about 3 times since late summer, and finally finished it last week. It's an excellent story but, I just had some issues with the writing style. It's a style that one reviewer describes as a "hot mess". I tend to agree.

Commonwealth, begins with a christening party in Southern, CA for Fix and Beverly Keating's second child, Franny. At the party there are far too many people, too much alcohol and an uninvited guest who works with Fix that shows up. Before the evening is up, two families will be torn apart.

Bert Cousins, is the uninvited guest. He's a man who can't deal with spending his weekend with his three small kids and pregnant wife. He leaves home and shows up at the party with a bottle of gin. Bert has always been a womanizer and at this event it's Beverly Keating who proves just too irresistible for Bert. One kiss, and a mutual instant attraction and soon two fractured families. Bert and Beverly move from CA back to Bert's home state of VA.

The title "Commonwealth" is significant and, the story follows the children and adults of these marriages through middle and old age. The family saga is large in scope. It's complicated, dysfunctional and even tragic. Yet, despite the sad parts, at times I found myself laughing as I read. The characters are well drawn and for the most part memorable.

The non linear writing style was hard for me to get used to. The story, although very good, kept moving from one character to another and, the constant shift in POV felt off putting after a while. Despite my struggles with this one, I loved the way that the author chose to end this family drama.

3.5/5 stars

text:

While reading other reviews, I'm shocked that they mention that they couldn't believe how this played out. Really? I guessed it from almost the very beginning.
It does have a good pace and storyline and was an overall enjoyable read but I wish I hadn't been able to guess the ending right from the beginning.

title: When Life Gives You Lemons
text: This is the upbeat telling of an Olympic gymnast's life story. From athletic triumph to confronting cancer, she applies herself one hundred percent. The best parts are when she recounts her Olympic success.  But she tends to gloss over the unpleasant and difficult times in her life including her marital disappointments. There is a lack of depth and introspection and while I certainly applauded her bright and cheerful attitude and  admired her many accomplishments, I did not find myself involved with her or her story at any meaningful level. I suppose that part of the cheerful veneer is being in the public eye at a tender age and part is for protection. She is an appropriate role model for young girls and those with a strong interest in gymnastics will enjoy this book. It is nicely written and readable but for me, the lemonade was just a bit too sweet.

title: It was a chore reading this over-rated book
text:
Despite having many good ideas, the writing was tedious, pompous, and self-impressed. Reading became a chore.
I don't know how this book got so many good reviews. Maybe it is similar to the book A Brief History of Time by Stephen Hawking. People don't actually read it; they just praise it.
Any book by Malcolm Gladwell is far more engaging. Or try reading Thinking Fast and Slow by Daniel Kahneman for a really excellent set of ideas.
Just nudge the book Nudge aside. It's too ponderous.
